content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

I would choose strategy B{B} as my move. The reasoning behind this is that in this game, both strategies have a "dominant" move from the opponent's perspective: if they want to maximize their earnings, they will pick R because it pays more when the other player picks B (35$ compared to 0$). However, I would like to ensure that my earnings are as high as possible regardless of what my opponent does.

In the long run, considering the game has 75 rounds, if I consistently choose strategy B, there will be a higher likelihood of getting the higher payoff (40$) when my opponent also chooses strategy B, rather than having no earnings when they pick R. Additionally, by choosing B, I have the potential to earn 35$ in situations where my opponent picks R.

Overall, while there might be short-term advantages for picking strategy R at certain points during the game, consistently going with strategy B seems more beneficial in maximizing earnings over the long run (75 rounds). However, it is important to note that this analysis assumes that the opponent will play optimally and pick R when I choose B. If the opponent is less predictable or not playing optimally, then my decision may need to be adjusted accordingly.
